subject: Alert user of need and ability to change expired password

comments.message:

Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.

Build Successful

Patch Set 2:

Thank you for testing in Firefox, Chrome and Safari. Can you please test in Edge and IE 11?

(5 comments)

The changes look reasonable to me, in particular detecting the PasswordChangeRequired condition, and setting the new password.  I did not review the full code flow.

Patch Set 6:

The code looks good. I would want someone to test on Edge and IE 11 before we +1 it.

Patch Set 6:

Minor corner case: After successfully setting the expired password and getting the login page with the message ”Successfully changed password.” If I try to login with an incorrect password, I see two messages “Successfully changed password” and “Invalid Username of Password. Please try again.”.
I don't think both should be displayed.

Patch Set 6:

Gunnar...Do we need a story to resolve the small edge case? Do we know when this will be included in master. I expect we have this downstream already.

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> Gunnar...Do we need a story to resolve the small edge case? Do we know when this will be included in master. I expect we have this downstream already.

I am fine with this being merged as is. Edge case.

Patch Set 6:

Still waiting on backend

Haven't been super strict with this, but can you follow the 50/72 rule for commit msgs. 
50 chars for the subject line / 72 chars for the body of the commmit msg. 

https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/
    Separate subject from body with a blank line
    Limit the subject line to 50 characters
    Capitalize the subject line
    Do not end the subject line with a period
    Use the imperative mood in the subject line
    Wrap the body at 72 characters
    Use the body to explain what and why vs. how

Mira, the easiest way to do this is to use VS Code to create the message. It will alert you when you have gone over and then you can just paste into the terminal window when the commit message is shown.
This does the same thing updateUser does. Should we reuse that?

FYA, if the session has PasswordChangeRequired, the underlying REST API (PATCH /redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/<user>) only allows the "Password" property to be updated.  I am not familiar with the updateUser function; if it limits itself to supplying only the "Password" property, then using should be okay.

Any thougths on refactoring this?
Maybe a future commit?

This ought to check the content of the extendedMessage field.  For example, check if the message begins with: "The password for this account must be changed"...
On the other hand, the extendedMessage is only used for this one purpose, and is not likely to have any other content.  I would prefer to see this check added, but will allow the code as-is.

When the webui switches over to Redfish (but not now!), this code will need to change .  It will need to check for the Redfish message like:
if (response.data["@Message.ExtendedInfo"]["MessageId"] ends with "PasswordChangeRequired")

I realize Redfish isn't important now, but it would be much nicer to have an ID for us to determine what the extended message is for. It's great that we are sending a message from the backend for this, e.g. "The password for this account must be changed", if we are expecting to display it to the user in the GUI. If so, we couldn't change the message without having to update the check. Also, we will be adding language translation and may need to map these extended messages to strings that we can translate on the client-side. 

If the extended message is not supposed to a message that is displayed to the user and is just to indicate the password needs to be changed, seems like the string could be shortened to remove any possibility for typo errors, i.e. I like PasswordChangeRequired. :)

Agreed.  A message id (such as PasswordChangeRequired) would have been nice.  The design is re-opened for review, here: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/25413/2/designs/expired-password.md#178

However, I understand the /login URI is deprecated, and the webui is moving to use Redfish SessionService for an upcoming release.  IMHO we should just keep the code on line 21 as-is.

Are you sure about the login URI being deprecated? According to Ed, we were not going to be able to handle the auth cookies with Redfish, so I didn't think there was a plan for login to be moved to redfish.

Oops, that was my error.  The /login URI is not deprecated.  (I had conflated it with the   legacy REST APIs, which I understand are deprecated and being replaced by Redfish APIs.)

However, the CSRF (aka XSRF) cookie is only needed to protect cookie-based session authentication (such as used by the phosphor-webui).  XSRF protection is not needed for Token based session authentication, such as using X-Auth-Token headers per the REDFISH cheatsheet.  So ... if phosphor-webui switched to login Redfish SessionService, and used the resulting X-Auth-Token to perform operations during that session, then XSRF cookies are not needed.
I'm working to explain authentication topics in the openbmc email list.

Meanwhile, back to the question about what to check: The openbmctool performs checking similar to the check performed here: lines 284 and 285 here: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc-tools/+/26123/4/thalerj/openbmctool.py#284
That is, I think the check should be:
if ((response.data['extendedMessage']) and (response.data['extendedMessage'].begins_with('The password for this account must be changed'))) ...

The format should be to stack grouped selectors

#login__form,
#expiredPassword__form {...}

Also, naming convention is not to use cameCase in selector naming. Can we update to #expired-password__form.

Based on the BEM syntax, it would appear there is an expiredPassword Block level element that contains a form. If that is not true, I would rename to expired-password-form.

Why are we using an id selector rather than a class selector? It is a best practice to avoid styling id's. I see it throughout the app, but we shouldn't continue that practice.
Roll this back once you have converted to using a page alert instead of a toast message.

Unless we are targeting the DOM node using the id, we can change this to a class element. I "think" the only purpose of this is to associate CSS styles. If that is true, I would change the id attribute to a class attribute and update the naming since we don't use cameCase naming for selectors. Also, I don't see an expiredPassword block level containers, so this form is the block and the the element. BEM (Block, Element, Modifier) naming convention indicates this is a child element of a block container titled expiredPassword and I don't believe that is true. 

I suggest changing the value to expired-password-form.
I think these values are dynamic? can we show this here?
maybe add a message when passwords don't match. Also not sure the other validations are needed here as long as the new password field is valid and this input matches
We don't need the toast service on this page any longer.
I agree and also, I am wondering if isPasswordValid the right name. If we are checking if the password is expired, would it be better to name the parameter isPasswordExpired?

FYA, Redfish started calling this condition passwordExpired and changed it to the more generic term PasswordChangeRequired.  Going forward, that's what the Redfish APIs will tell us.

However, OpenBMC currently only has passwordExpired which maps to PasswordChangeRequired.  This will only become important if we ever have another way to induce the PasswordChangeRequired condition.
Are you checking the form is valid before making the call to change password? The markup doesn't seem to disable the submit button and there are no checks here
Great point -- I disabled the button when the form isn't touched or is invalid.
I haven't tested the flow in the GUI, but are we redirecting the user back to login or logging them into the server overview?
Redirecting to login is what I saw in the demo
Is there anyway to map backend error here to a more useful message in the GUI? this seems like an important part of the flow to provide meaningful feedback

Sorry, at this time the change password REST API is not able to provide any details about what went wrong.  I've noted this in https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/issues/103 but we might want more focus on this.
We do need to remove the toast and replace with an alert.
I will revert the spacing back.
I wanted to target all the labels within this form, so used label instead of classname

Resolve any use of camelCase in the naming and validate the BEM naming, please. :)

.expired__password__status-icon means status-icon is an Element of password, which is an Element of expired. I suggest expired-password-status-icon.

Isn't this just a truthy check?

if (response.data['extendedMessage']) {...}
good point -- I will change it, thank you!

This is a boolean check...truthy check would be:

ng-if="isPasswordValid"

Testing for the boolean is not needed. Same on all the other's below on line 15.

Same as the other statement, but in this case to test as falsy:

ng-if="!isPasswordValid"

No need to test for the boolean. This is true in every ng-if statement on the page where the boolean of true or false is being evaluated.
Is this else if needed? It seems like we can set $scope.isPasswordValid = isPasswordValid in the first line of the function.
it is needed, because I don't want the other if and else statements to be executed if the password is not valid.

did you try using the existing updateUser method? 
updateUser($scope.username, null, $scope.passwordReset.confirmPassword)
that works! I updated it -- thanks!!
Can we remove these empty line changes?
I thought I had removed that

Can we update this to follow best practices?

- Change the selector to a class instead of an id
- Use a dash (-) to separate words. expiredPasswordForm = expired-password-form
I am having issues changing the id to include dashes in its name.
It should be a class opposed to an id. Why are we stying an id?
changed it to the class -- thank you.
.expired-password__btns? Line 33 is using the same naming and they should follow the same naming contention and be consistent.
I don't think you are using this now.
If you delete this empty line it fixes the spaces between the input fields (tested in chrome and firefox)
If you delete this empty line it fixes the spaces between the input fields (tested in chrome and firefox)
why .expired__password when you are using .expired-password selector in other rulesets?
Realized I am not even using this, so removed it -- thanks.
